DeregistrationReasonOtherText: Quantity of regulatory substance was erroneously calculated for initial RMP

_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: pump system, it was properly operating to ensure after release
_prev_prog_2.Description: Technic operates one RMP ?covered process,? which involves the storage, distribution, and processing of a 28% solution of aqueous ammonia as part of the powder production process.  One ammonia tank is located at the rear of the facility, outside the building behind waste treatment.  Ammonia may also be located in piping and mixing tanks within the powder production areas of the site.  This prevention program covers all aspects of the ammonia distribution and storage at the site.

_accidents.CI_OtherType: clearer marking for pipes and valves

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Technic Engineered Powders (Technic), a private corporation, is one of the largest global producers of metal

particulates for the photovoltaic and electronics industries. At its 300 Park East Drive facility in Woonsocket, Rhode

Island, metal powders and flake are manufactured for the electronics, electrical, jewelry, aerospace, medical, and

dental industries. The 93,000 sq. ft. Technic facility is situated on a twelve-acre plot in an industrial park, with a

predominantly rural surrounding. The closest residence, closest commercial/industrial establishment, and closest

navigable water body are all located approximately 0.1 miles from the site.

Technic operates one RMP "covered process," which involves the storage, distribution, and processing of a 28%

solution of aqueous ammonia. One ammonia tank is located at the rear of the facility, outside the building behind

waste treatment. Ammonia may also be located in piping and mixing tanks within the powder production areas of the

building. One pump, located at the main ammonia tank, serves all the powder production lines.

Ammonia is a colorless gas with a pungent odor. It is one of the most widely produced chemicals in the United

States and also occurs naturally in the human body (as a building block for making proteins and other complex

molecules) and in nature (in soil from bacterial processes and from plant and animal decay). Its distinct odor is

familiar to many people, even at low levels, because ammonia is used in smelling salts and household cleaners (e.g.,

window-cleaning products). When anhydrous ammonia is dissolved in water, it is called liquid ammonia, ammonium

hydroxide, or aqueous ammonia. Aqueous ammonia is not flammable, but can be toxic, and use of aqueous

ammonia is a safer alternative than anhydrous ammonia. Technic uses only aqueous ammonia at the site.

In 2008, Technic filed a Program Level 1 RMP; however, an August 5, 2011 accidental release of aqueous ammonia

cau

sed Technic to become subject to Program Level 2. The release was caused by human error in handling totes

that were brought onsite as a temporary measure. Up to twenty gallons of aqueous ammonia were released to

Technic's wastewater treatment system, but did not migrate offsite or impact any environmental or population

receptors. As a result of the release, Technic revised operating procedures, upgraded equipment labeling, and

secured additional communication devices to prevent a similar release from occurring.

Technic personnel do not respond to spills beyond the incidental level. Spills that are not incidental in nature require

the services of a spill response contractor or other outside responder. To ensure that the facility is adequately

prepared in the event of a release, Technic has an established relationship with local emergency planning personnel.

The Woonsocket Fire Department serves as the LEPC, and is familiar with the hazards of aqueous ammonia.

Technic also has the following plans and programs in place at the facility:

?<The Emergency Response/Emergency Action Plan addresses coordination with agencies, emergency

recognition and prevention, lines of authority, communication, security, evacuation, emergency response and

cleanup procedures.

?<The Hazardous Waste Contingency Plan addresses response elements related to identification and cleanup of

hazardous waste, including those that may result from a spill event.

?<The HAZCOM training program provides employees the necessary background to identify workplace hazards,

interpret MSDS and labels, obtain personal protection equipment, and have a general awareness of emergency

procedures for the site.

?<An established management system, including an RMP Program Coordinator, oversees the implementation of

the RMP elements.

?<Operating, inspection, testing, and maintenance procedures ensure that aqueous ammonia is safely stored and

used.

?<The RMP audit program requires that at least one pe

rson knowledgeable in the ammonia process conduct an

audit every three years to verify that the procedures and practices developed under 40 C.F.R. 68 are adequate

and are being followed.

As required by 40 C.F.R. 68, Technic conducted an offsite consequence analysis to predict potential impact during a

release. Technic's worst-case release scenario is based on the most conservative meteorological conditions and an

instantaneous, catastrophic release of the aqueous ammonia tank into a liquid pool that is contained by the passive

mitigation system. The alternative release scenario is based on expected meteorological conditions and a more

realistic release scenario that is similar to the August 2011 release. To determine the alternative scenario, Technic

conducted a hazard analysis, reviewed the five year accident history, and considered the ways that aqueous

ammonia is used in the process. Technic used RMP*Comp to approximate a distance to toxic endpoint of 0.4 mile at

a rate of 583 ft/min for the worst-case release, and <0.1 miles (assumed to equal 0.1 miles) at a rate of 33.4 lbs/min

for the alternative release. The distance to toxic endpoint is the distance that an accidental release of aqueous

ammonia from this facility could travel under the modeled conditions. US Geological Survey (USGS) maps, Rhode

Island Geographic Information Systems (RIGIS) data, and Landview 6 estimated no environmental receptors for the

worst-case or alternative scenario. Landview 6 estimated a 623 population receptors within the distance to toxic

endpoint for the worst-case scenario and no population receptors for the alternative scenario

Additional details on Technic's RMP Program are available in the Program Level 2 RMP Plan, which is available

onsite and by specific request. The plan is updated every five years or more often if necessary. Additional

information, including RMP program updates and submissions, can be found at

http://yosemite.epa.gov/oswer/ceppoweb.nsf/c
